articles.headline: Canada Toughens Stance on Protests, Promising ‘Robust’ Police Response
articles.snippet: After treading lightly for weeks, officials obtained a court order to halt the blockade of a major route to the United States. They also vowed fines and arrests.
articles.abstract: After treading lightly for weeks, officials obtained a court order to halt the blockade of a major route to the United States. They also vowed fines and arrests.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — After weeks of treading lightly around the protests paralyzing much of Canada’s economy, federal, provincial and local officials adopted a markedly tougher approach on Friday, threatening protesters with arrests and heavy fines, and obtaining a court order to halt the blockade of a major route to the United States.

articles.headline: In Reversal, F.D.A. Delays Push for Shots for Children Under 5
articles.snippet: The agency will wait for data on whether three doses of Pfizer-BioNTech’s Covid vaccine are effective in young children after new, disappointing data.
articles.abstract: The agency will wait for data on whether three doses of Pfizer-BioNTech’s Covid vaccine are effective in young children after new, disappointing data.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a striking reversal, federal regulators said on Friday that they would wait for data on how well three doses of Pfizer-BioNTech’s coronavirus vaccine work in children younger than 5 before deciding whether to authorize the vaccine for that age group.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland

articles.headline: Business Booms at Kroger-Owned Grocery Stores, but Workers Are Left Behind
articles.snippet: A number of the stores’ nearly 500,000 employees have reported being homeless, receiving government food stamps or relying on food banks.
articles.abstract: A number of the stores’ nearly 500,000 employees have reported being homeless, receiving government food stamps or relying on food banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Enrique Romero Jr. finishes his shift fulfilling online orders at a Fred Meyer grocery store in Bellingham, Wash., he often walks to a nearby plasma donation center. There, he has his blood drained, and a hydrating solution is pumped into his veins, a process that leaves him tired and cold.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Far From the Big City, New Economic Life
articles.snippet: Incomes are low in small-town Tennessee, but so is the cost of living. That attraction could be a key to reviving many rural areas.
articles.abstract: Incomes are low in small-town Tennessee, but so is the cost of living. That attraction could be a key to reviving many rural areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAINESBORO, Tenn. — There is not much to suggest prosperity in Gainesboro, a hamlet of 920 in Tennessee’s Upper Cumberland region. Almost one in seven homes are vacant. One-quarter of the population lives in poverty.
articles.byline: By Eduardo Porter and Stacy Kranitz

articles.headline: Selling Trump: A Profitable Post-Presidency Like No Other
articles.snippet: Much as he did while in the White House, Donald Trump has thoroughly blurred the lines between his political ambitions and his business interests, with a wide-ranging set of moneymaking ventures.
articles.abstract: Much as he did while in the White House, Donald Trump has thoroughly blurred the lines between his political ambitions and his business interests, with a wide-ranging set of moneymaking ventures.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early December, Donald J. Trump put on a tuxedo and boarded the private jet of a scrap-metal magnate and crypto-miner for a short flight across Florida, touching down at an airport in Naples. There, a long red carpet marked the pathway into a Christmas-decorated hangar filled with supporters of Mr. Trump who had paid $10,000 to $30,000 for the privilege of attending a party and taking a photo with him.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: When Working for Racial Justice Means Taking Black History Month Off
articles.snippet: The period when firms are ordinarily flooded with requests instead became a reminder, for clients, that this work should persist all throughout the year.
articles.abstract: The period when firms are ordinarily flooded with requests instead became a reminder, for clients, that this work should persist all throughout the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rhonda Broussard spent two decades performing with West African dance groups in her free time. She would wait around all year for gigs — until February when her calendar was jammed.

articles.headline: In Ottawa Protests, a Pressing Question: Where Were the Police?
articles.snippet: They were vastly outnumbered, experts say, and unprepared for the sophisticated tactics, discipline and logistical abilities of the protesters.
articles.abstract: They were vastly outnumbered, experts say, and unprepared for the sophisticated tactics, discipline and logistical abilities of the protesters.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Steps from Canada’s Parliament buildings, a sprawling festival erupted on Saturday. D.J.s played music for crowds dancing at intersections, singers belted out songs from an improvised stage and protesters’ trucks still blocked the streets, blowing their horns to cheers.

articles.headline: U.S. Battles Putin by Disclosing His Next Possible Moves
articles.snippet: Declassified information is part of a campaign to complicate what officials say are Russia’s plans to invade Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Declassified information is part of a campaign to complicate what officials say are Russia’s plans to invade Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After decades of getting schooled in information warfare by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, the United States is trying to beat the master at his own game.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Making ‘Dinobabies’ Extinct: IBM’s Push for a Younger Work Force
articles.snippet: Documents released in an age-discrimination case appear to show high-level discussion about paring the ranks of older employees.
articles.abstract: Documents released in an age-discrimination case appear to show high-level discussion about paring the ranks of older employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent years, former IBM employees have accused the company of age discrimination in a variety of legal filings and press accounts, arguing that IBM sought to replace thousands of older workers with younger ones to keep pace with corporate rivals.

articles.headline: U.S. Pulls Most Diplomats From Kyiv as Tensions Mount
articles.snippet: Western officials made another diplomatic push on Saturday to dissuade President Vladimir V. Putin from invading Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Western officials made another diplomatic push on Saturday to dissuade President Vladimir V. Putin from invading Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — President Biden warned President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia that invading Ukraine would result in “swift and severe” costs to Russia, diminish his country’s standing and cause “widespread human suffering,” the White House said on Saturday, as Western officials made a forceful diplomatic push to dissuade Mr. Putin from pressing forward with an attack.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer, Anton Troianovski, Katie Rogers and Lara Jakes

articles.headline: Inglewood Has Experienced Dramatic Change. The Super Bowl Is Proof of That.
articles.snippet: With a glittering N.F.L. stadium and a new N.B.A. arena on the way, the city of Inglewood, Calif., is celebrating its progress. But on the streets, stark disparities linger.
articles.abstract: With a glittering N.F.L. stadium and a new N.B.A. arena on the way, the city of Inglewood, Calif., is celebrating its progress. But on the streets, stark disparities linger.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow the Super Bowl live with Joe Burrow, Odell Beckham Jr, Matthew Stafford and Aaron Donald.]

articles.headline: Inside McConnell’s Campaign to Take Back the Senate and Thwart Trump
articles.snippet: Senator Mitch McConnell is working furiously to bring allies to Washington who will buck Donald J. Trump. It’s not going according to plan.
articles.abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell is working furiously to bring allies to Washington who will buck Donald J. Trump. It’s not going according to plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — For more than a year, former President Donald Trump has berated Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona, savaging him for refusing to overturn the state’s presidential results and vowing to oppose him should he run for the Senate this year.

articles.headline: In Arbery Hate Crimes Trial, Racism Will Take Center Stage
articles.snippet: Jurors in the unusual case will be asked to decide if the men who chased and killed Ahmaud Arbery were motivated by racial animus. The evidence they may consider includes explicitly racist language.
articles.abstract: Jurors in the unusual case will be asked to decide if the men who chased and killed Ahmaud Arbery were motivated by racial animus. The evidence they may consider includes explicitly racist language.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The killing of George Floyd catalyzed a period of national soul-searching about race and racism that has touched nearly every aspect of American life. But in a number of high-profile trials since then — including in the murder of Mr. Floyd and the killing of Ahmaud Arbery — prosecutors have carefully avoided putting racism itself on center stage.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Audra D. S. Burch

articles.headline: Divorcing Couples Fight Over the Kids, the House and Now the Crypto
articles.snippet: Dividing the family’s Bitcoin stash has become a major source of contention in divorce cases.
articles.abstract: Dividing the family’s Bitcoin stash has become a major source of contention in divorce cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: The divorce dragged on for eight years, almost as long as the marriage. The wealthy San Francisco couple sparred over child support, the profits from the sale of the husband’s software company and the fate of their $3.6 million home.

articles.headline: That Organic Cotton T-Shirt May Not Be as Organic as You Think
articles.snippet: The organic cotton movement in India appears to be booming, but much of this growth is fake, say those who source, process and grow the cotton.
articles.abstract: The organic cotton movement in India appears to be booming, but much of this growth is fake, say those who source, process and grow the cotton.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael Kors retails its organic cotton and recycled polyester women’s zip-up hoodies for $25 more than its conventional cotton hoodies. Urban Outfitters sells organic sweatpants that are priced $46 more than an equivalent pair of conventional cotton sweatpants. And Tommy Hilfiger’s men’s organic cotton slim-fit T-shirt is $3 more than its conventional counterpart.
articles.byline: By Alden Wicker, Emily Schmall, Suhasini Raj and Elizabeth Paton

articles.headline: Ukraine’s President Tries to Avert Panic as Pressure Mounts
articles.snippet: With Ukraine at the center of Europe’s most intense security crisis of the post-Cold War era, President Zelensky is driving home his message of optimism.
articles.abstract: With Ukraine at the center of Europe’s most intense security crisis of the post-Cold War era, President Zelensky is driving home his message of optimism.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Russian attack helicopters were spotted buzzing within miles of his country’s borders on Sunday. The last strands of diplomacy were unraveling. Allies evacuated their embassies, airlines canceled flights, and a large number of private jets departed from the capital.

articles.headline: Canada Opens Blockaded Bridge, but in Ottawa, Truckers Won’t Budge
articles.snippet: Amid progress at a border bridge, Ottawa remained frozen by an antigovernment protest. There were signs of a slight thaw, with truckers said to be weighing pulling out of part of the capital.
articles.abstract: Amid progress at a border bridge, Ottawa remained frozen by an antigovernment protest. There were signs of a slight thaw, with truckers said to be weighing pulling out of part of the capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Canadian law enforcement officials said Sunday that they had reopened a major international bridge that protesters had been blockading for almost a week, raising hopes for industries the unrest had slowed to a near-standstill.

articles.headline: Germany Tries to Loosen Its Ties to Russian Gas Pipelines
articles.snippet: An increasingly belligerent Russia, an energy crunch and a new Green minister of economics all add up to a change of direction in Germany’s policy on natural gas.
articles.abstract: An increasingly belligerent Russia, an energy crunch and a new Green minister of economics all add up to a change of direction in Germany’s policy on natural gas.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For decades, Germany has been a steadfast consumer of Russian natural gas, a relationship that has seemingly grown closer over the years, surviving Cold War-era tensions, the breakup of the former Soviet Union and even European sanctions against Moscow over its annexation of Crimea. Until this winter.

articles.headline: The Right’s Would-Be Kingmaker
articles.snippet: Peter Thiel, one of Donald J. Trump’s biggest donors in 2016, has re-emerged as a prime financier of the Make America Great Again movement.
articles.abstract: Peter Thiel, one of Donald J. Trump’s biggest donors in 2016, has re-emerged as a prime financier of the Make America Great Again movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: Energy Markets Are Jittery as Russia-Ukraine Tensions Drag On
articles.snippet: Oil prices are well over $90 a barrel, and an invasion would most likely push them above $100. Reflecting the uncertainty, stock markets were sliding lower.
articles.abstract: Oil prices are well over $90 a barrel, and an invasion would most likely push them above $100. Reflecting the uncertainty, stock markets were sliding lower.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Russian invasion of Ukraine could drive up already high oil and natural gas prices, prolonging elevated inflation around the world and dealing a blow to any country dependent on Russia for energy.

articles.headline: Judge Plans to Dismiss Sarah Palin’s Lawsuit Against The Times
articles.snippet: The jury will continue to deliberate. The judge indicated that he believed an appeal was likely, and his decision was intended to avoid any complications should that occur.
articles.abstract: The jury will continue to deliberate. The judge indicated that he believed an appeal was likely, and his decision was intended to avoid any complications should that occur.
articles.lead_paragraph: Update: The jury reached a verdict on Tuesday, rejecting Sarah Palin’s libel claim.

articles.headline: For China, Hosting the Olympics Is Worth Every Billion
articles.snippet: For many cities, the Games make no economic sense. National pride and an enthusiasm for building transportation infrastructure change the equation for Beijing.
articles.abstract: For many cities, the Games make no economic sense. National pride and an enthusiasm for building transportation infrastructure change the equation for Beijing.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZHANGJIAKOU, China — To make an Olympic ski jump, China clad a hillside in steel and blanketed it with artificial snow. To construct a high-speed rail line linking the venues and Beijing, engineers blasted tunnels through the surrounding mountains. And to keep the coronavirus at bay, workers are conducting tens of thousands of P.C.R. tests on Games participants every day.
